content: test
Hey @Quincy Larson . Welcome to Zulip :octopus:
Thanks! Thrilled to be here :)
Let us know if you have any questions about zulip (how it works, hosting, etc) or any other feedback as you poke around!
OK - cool Thanks
Howdy good sirs!
var test = "test";
var test = "test";
@Jonathan Grah Nice to see you here.

:wave:
sirs and madams :).
@Rishi Gupta I do have some questions
@Rishi Gupta is this the biggest instance of Zulip? I'm trying to figure out how big of a server freeCodeCamp would need if we were to deploy this.
@Rishi Gupta Also, what moderation tools are available? In case we got someone who was problematic (which we do occasionally on Gitter and on our forum)

This server has about 3000 users, and a few hundred weekly actives (chat.zulip.org/stats has some other stats). It runs on a single machine with 8gb of RAM (can try to find other machine stats as well).
The main moderation tools we have for that currently are that admins can delete messages, and admins can deactivate users.
@Rishi Gupta are there currently any roles or permissions for different levels of users?
We also allow some customization on the registration page, where you can link to a CoC or say a few words about expected behavior.
There's just organization admin and normal user. What sorts of things would be helpful?
The settings at https://chat.zulip.org/#organization/organization-profile might be helpful to peruse (to get a sense of admin options).

For example, having low level moderators (deleting messages, temporary banning users) and high level moderators (have control over the moderators and can permanently ban users or something like that)
The code of conduct feature would definitely be useful :+1:
Thanks i'll check that out
one thing that has been discussed is stream moderators, i.e. each stream could have users with admin-level permissions for anything relating to that stream. Would that solve some of the problem?
yes, that would definitely solve some of the problem. At the current time, is there anyway of disabling viewing of users emails?

yeah, that is an extremely requested feature :). It is a high priority, though I don't know the current status of the effort myself.
I think there is a quick hack one can do in the meantime if you are running your own server?
alright, that would probably be fine, I'd say we'd probably want to do that for privacy reasons, may put some people off joining

Sorry for the continuous asking of questions :P
Is globally banning people already an implemented feature?
I am not sure if what you mean by “banning” requires anything more (or less) than “deactivation”, which we support. Can you clarify?
And these are good questions. :grinning: We really value this type of feedback.
Thanks, could you give me the definition of how you refer to deactivation?
Deactivating a user prevents them from logging in.
It also removes them from things like typeahead and buddy lists. But you can still see their old messages.
It is reversible and often is used for users who aren’t banned, per se, but just no longer in the organization.
Alright, that is what we are looking for; that's great :)
@Quincy Larson do you have current numbers for how many total and concurrent users you folks have?
I can probably give you a more detailed opinion on whether it'll just work, or one will need to do a few things, or what, given that sort of data.
@Tim Abbott the freeCodeCamp forum has about 110 concurrent users at the moment. I'd say it ranges between 60 and 200. I'm not sure whether chat will be similar.
(deleted)
How far back does Zulip's search go? I searched for "Python" and wasn't getting results beyond October 31.
I moved this conversation to the topic "search issues".
OK; if you have that scale of concurrent issues, we definitely don't need to worry about that from a scalability perspective.

@Quincy Larson do you also have a number for how many total users you have? Anything below 5K is clearly no problem as we have several orgs at that size; up to 10K, we haven't tested with real workloads (as opposed to scalability testing tools), but I think it's unlikely to require more than a couple optimizations (which we'd be happy to do).

test reply

const reply = () => {};
@Jonathan Grah for sending test messages in this community, we generally recommend folks use #test here, so it doesn't interrupt actual conversations :)
I'm unsure how many campers would use Zulip. We have 1m+ people using freecodecamp.org every month, so it could be a lot if chat becomes popular.

@Quincy Larson Would you mind if I created a stream to discuss freecodecamp.org? I can make it either public or private. If I make it private, I'll invite a couple core Zulip people. It's also fine to continue the discussion here, although #general may be slightly more appropriate then #design.
Should we try using #user community? It'd be nice to have discussion be publicly archived/findable-ish for other projects that come by.
Yeah, let's do that.
(deleted)
